page.title: 08HOUSING IN GRETTON
page.content: Housing in Gretton can be split into three different types. Firstly, the houses of the old village which are situated around the Parish Church. These are mainly built of stone and originally had thatched roofs, most of which have now been replaced by tiles. Secondly, in 1920, again in 1931, and again in the late 1950's council houses were added extending the village towards the south-east. Thirdly, in the 1970's, Gretton was further extended by the building of 80 new houses in a private estate. The oldest house in the village is what used to be the Manor House. This now needs so much repair that no-one lives in it. Gretton House, a large stone building which used to be a rehabilitation centre belonging to the British Steel Corporation, is now a home for handicapped people.
